meaning_mnemonic: When how much you <kanji>prosper</kanji> goes into your <kanji>heart</kanji> and just enters a <kanji>void</kanji>, it will rarely mean anything to you. A person who has this trait is going to have extreme <vocabulary>vanity</vocabulary> because he/she just needs to suck more and more prosperity into their bottomless pit of a heart. It's like a black hole. They need more and more and more so then they have to become vain.

You <kanji>pray</kanji> with your <kanji>thought</kanji>s, making this a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>.

While 祈願 is about formally asking a specific deity for something, 祈念 refers to <vocabulary>praying</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wishing</vocabulary> in a more silent and personal sense. It's used in formal situations to express hopes for success, safety, peace, or recovery, and often appears in names of monuments or events that combine remembrance and hope, such as 平和祈念公園 (Peace Memorial Park) or 復興祈念イベント (Reconstruction Prayer Event).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>misguided</kanji>, but the verb version is usually used to describe how you feel after being misguided — <vocabulary>to be at a loss</vocabulary>!

惑う usually refers to being in a quandary or a state of confusion. Using 惑う is kind of old-fashioned, but other forms like 惑わせる and 逃げ惑う (to flee frantically) are still fairly common in modern Japanese.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same, so this also means <vocabulary>deep red</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>crimson</vocabulary>. Additionally, it can also mean <vocabulary>rouge</vocabulary>, usually in reference to the cosmetic.

紅 is also a bit of an old-fashioned and somewhat literary word, so keep that in mind!
This is the noun version of 香, making it have the same meaning, <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>join</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is when in one play you get two kills (outs) in baseball, making it a <vocabulary>double play</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Commander</kanji> <kanji>chess piece</kanji> is a game known as <vocabulary>shogi</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Japanese chess</vocabulary>, but <vocabulary>shogi</vocabulary> is better). It's similar to chess in a lot of ways and it's pretty interesting. Check it out if you already like chess.

The <kanji>traces</kanji> are the people that <kanji>inherit</kanji> what you have. They are your <vocabulary>heir</vocabulary>s or <vocabulary>heiress</vocabulary>es. Your <vocabulary>successor</vocabulary>.
Not to be confused with 跳ぶ, this word has the same meaning. The reading is different, however.
A <kanji>rope</kanji> that you <kanji>hop</kanji> over is a <vocabulary>jump rope</vocabulary>. 縄跳び can also refer to the activity of <vocabulary>jumping rope</vocabulary> (aka skipping rope).
If 応募 is "application" then the verb version is <vocabulary>to apply for</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to enlist</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>hit</kanji> you get in <kanji>baseball</kanji> that takes you to the <kanji>origin</kanji> plate is a <vocabulary>home run</vocabulary>. HOOOMMEERUNNNN!

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>crumble</kanji> and the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to crumble</vocabulary>, like, something is crumbling or collapsing.

払い is a "payment" and 戻す is "to return." If you return a payment, you are going <vocabulary>to repay</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to refund</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to reimburse</vocabulary> someone for their payment.

You'd think that this means "to bullet" but it does not. It means <vocabulary>to play a stringed instrument</vocabulary>. It's actually used for all stringed instruments, and all instruments with a keyboard, like pianos and electric keyboards. Just imagine taking a bullet and using it as a pick for a guitar, then using it to press down the keys of a piano and play a tune.
You may remember 言葉 means "word" and 遣う means "to use." That makes this your <vocabulary>choice of words</vocabulary> or, more simply, your <vocabulary>word use</vocabulary>.

遣う means "to use," so a "<kanji>small</kanji> use" refers to what you can do with your <vocabulary>spending money</vocabulary>. You're not rolling in dough over here, so you can only use your spending money on small things. Think of it like a little <vocabulary>allowance</vocabulary> you can use to buy baseball cards and bubblegum and stuff.
If 削除 is "deletion," then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to delete</vocabulary>.
A 掲示 is a notice or sign. Put this on a <kanji>board</kanji>, and it becomes a <vocabulary>bulletin board</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>bitter</kanji> <kanji>stagnate</kanji> is when you're stagnated in traffic. It feels bitter, doesn't it? Why can't people drive faster? Why are people looking at the accident instead of driving? I'm so bitter about it! That's why this word is <vocabulary>traffic jam</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>traffic congestion</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Recruit</kanji> and <kanji>gather</kanji> everyone to the <kanji>middle</kanji>. They're all here gathering for this recruitment because we're <vocabulary>now hiring</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>now recruiting</vocabulary>.
If 戻る is "to <kanji>return</kanji>" then you return on the <kanji>street</kanji> you came from, you are taking the <vocabulary>way back</vocabulary>.
To <kanji>take</kanji> and <kanji>return</kanji> something to yourself is <vocabulary>to take back</vocabulary> something. Give it back!
原子 is atom and 爆弾 is bomb. What is an atom bomb? An <vocabulary>atomic bomb</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Foot</kanji> <kanji>traces</kanji> are <vocabulary>footprint</vocabulary>s.
Remember 狙い and how it means "aim"? Make that into a verb, and you have <vocabulary>to aim at</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>translation</kanji> is a translation to your home country's language. Since this is a Japanese word, this translation would be a <vocabulary>translation into Japanese</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>home country</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>fellow countryman</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>compatriot</vocabulary> (only for Japanese people though). In Japan, you're a <vocabulary>Japanese national</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Take along</kanji> your <kanji>home country</kanji> to all the other spaces you want to add to your group. Put them together to form the <vocabulary>commonwealth</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>federation</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>buzzer</kanji> that will <kanji>call</kanji> you to the door is a <vocabulary>doorbell</vocabulary>.

The meaning for this word comes from the kanji. It's a <vocabulary>small bell</vocabulary>!

鈴 typically refers to small, spherical bells that jingle or tinkle — think sleigh bells or the bell on a dog collar, or the bells hanging in Japanese shrines that visitors ring before praying (though these can range in size).
The <kanji>branch off</kanji> <kanji>mound</kanji> is the area of Japan known as <vocabulary>Gifu</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Prosperity</kanji> in <kanji>piles</kanji> is a lot of <vocabulary>prosperity</vocabulary>!

When <kanji>prosperity</kanji> <kanji>wakes up</kanji> it will push through whatever it's in and create a <vocabulary>protuberance</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>bulge</vocabulary>. Just imagine it pushing out of the wall, trying to get out, making a bulge. So prosperous!
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>employ</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to employ</vocabulary>.

You are going to <kanji>untie</kanji> the person who is in your <kanji>employ</kanji> from being employed with you. They are free. This means you fired them, which is why this verb means <vocabulary>to fire someone</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>employ</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji> is <vocabulary>employment</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>wall</kanji>'s <kanji>paper</kanji> is <vocabulary>wallpaper</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>chess piece</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is someone who plays chess or go, making this word a <vocabulary>shogi player</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>go player</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>chess piece</kanji> <kanji>institution</kanji> is where you go to play chess... or, in Japan, it's not chess, it's a <vocabulary>Go hall</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>Go club</vocabulary> (it's a very interesting game you should look it up!).

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The adjective form of <kanji>bitter</kanji> is <vocabulary>bitter</vocabulary>, or more specifically, a <vocabulary>bitter flavor</vocabulary>.

Something that is <kanji>one-sided</kanji> has only one side and not the whole. That's just <vocabulary>one of a pair</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fragment</vocabulary> of the whole. Stick this onto another word and you have one of a pair or an "incomplete_____."
A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>hand</kanji> is one of your hands, that means you're doing something <vocabulary>one handed</vocabulary>.

<kanji>One sided</kanji> <kanji>say</kanji>ing things means you don't know both sides of the language, causing you to speak in <vocabulary>broken language</vocabulary>, for example speaking <vocabulary>a few words</vocabulary> in <vocabulary>broken Japanese</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>broken English</vocabulary>.
<kanji>One-sided</kanji> <kanji>kana</kanji> is <vocabulary>katakana</vocabulary>. Might be easier to do the reading first on this one.
A <kanji>one sided</kanji> <kanji>street</kanji> is for <vocabulary>one way</vocabulary> only, because everything just goes in one direction.
This is the noun version of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>flock</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>flock</kanji> of <kanji>horse</kanji>s <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is the part of Japan known as <vocabulary>Gunma Prefecture</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>flock</kanji> that has <kanji>gather</kanji>ed is a <vocabulary>crowd</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>multitude</vocabulary>. Because, well, lots of things gathering.
A <kanji>hermit</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hermit</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>mountain man</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>hermit</kanji>, for some reason, is a <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>. Just imagine a water hermit dancing around picking <vocabulary>daffodil</vocabulary>s, because he loves 'em! Yayyy daffodils!!
The <kanji>hermit</kanji> <kanji>machine</kanji> is a giant machine that lives in the <vocabulary>Sendai</vocabulary> area of Japan.
<kanji>Allocate</kanji> the <kanji>truth</kanji> more and more to make things better. The truth is, we need to allocate even more, until we've reached <vocabulary>fullness</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Allocate</kanji> <kanji>electricity</kanji> back to the battery with a <vocabulary>recharge</vocabulary>.

To take a <kanji>supplement</kanji> and <kanji>allocate</kanji> it to where it needs to be is to <vocabulary>resupply</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>refill</vocabulary> something.

補充 means filling in the gaps when there's a shortage. It's used for things like <vocabulary>restock</vocabulary>ing supplies, replacing what's been used, or adding more staff to meet demand. The goal is to bring things back to a needed or complete level.

You are going to <kanji>excuse</kanji> yourself from the situation, and in order to do that, you have <vocabulary>to escape from</vocabulary> the person / thing trying to hold you there in order <vocabulary>to avoid</vocabulary> them.
Your <kanji>excuse</kanji> for the current <kanji>condition</kanji> is surprising, especially considering your <vocabulary>diploma</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>license</vocabulary> on the issue.
You have an <kanji>excuse</kanji> that <kanji>permit</kanji>s you to do what you want. It is a <vocabulary>license</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>certificate</vocabulary> allowing you to do this.
An <kanji>excuse</kanji> from <kanji>tax</kanji>es? That's a <vocabulary>tax exemption</vocabulary>.
An <kanji>honorable</kanji> <kanji>excuse</kanji> is all I have, and that is no good. I'm <vocabulary>sorry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>I beg your pardon</vocabulary>.

To <kanji>excuse</kanji> and to <kanji>exclude</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>exemption</vocabulary>.

免除 means granting relief or exemption from a duty or obligation that would otherwise be required, like paying tuition fees, repaying debts, obtaining specific licenses for certain activities, and so on.
If you take what you <kanji>recommend</kanji> and <kanji>announce</kanji> it to the world, you are making a <vocabulary>recommendation</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>range</kanji> is <kanji>outside</kanji> of the range, meaning you're <vocabulary>out of range</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>range</kanji> is the areas where people speak English, aka the <vocabulary>English Speaking World</vocabulary>.
Remember how 南極 means "South Pole" or the "Antarctic"? Add <kanji>range</kanji> onto that word and you get the region known as the <vocabulary>Antarctic Circle</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>cape</kanji> <kanji>ball</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Saitama Prefecture</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rob</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rob</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>honorable</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>. It's the meal of Japan.

Add an <kanji>honorable</kanji> little 御 for someone to <kanji>look at</kanji> when you want to show respect to them. 御覧になる is the honorific form of 見る, so it still means <vocabulary>to look</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to see</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to watch</vocabulary>, but with a more respectful tone.

You'll often use it when someone of higher status than you is doing the looking and you want to sound like a polite, refined adult who's showing proper respect to them. Keep in mind that the first 御 is often written in kana, like ご覧になる.
If you have <kanji>humility</kanji> you will try <vocabulary>to be discreet</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Humility</kanji> is <kanji>heavy</kanji>, so it's best nobody knows your secret. You should be <vocabulary>discreet</vocabulary> instead.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>refuse</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to refuse</vocabulary>.
I <kanji>refuse</kanji>. I am saying "<kanji>no</kanji>." That is my <vocabulary>refusal</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
The <kanji>frame</kanji> <kanji>group</kanji> is a <vocabulary>frame</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>framework</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

甲 has traditionally meant <vocabulary>turtle shell</vocabulary>, but these days it appears much more often in expressions like 足の甲 (<vocabulary>instep</vocabulary>) and 手の甲 (<vocabulary>back of the hand</vocabulary>). If you think about it, those body parts kind of resemble turtle shells, don’t you think?

A <kanji>turtle shell</kanji> that is <kanji>patterned</kanji> has much more <vocabulary>worth</vocabulary> than a boring non-patterned turtle shell. It probably has a better <vocabulary>effect</vocabulary> too if you throw it at your opponent in a go-kart race or something — give it a shot and see what the <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> is!

甲斐 doesn't mean "worth" in the sense of monetary value, but rather in the sense that some action you took paid off or was worth doing. You'll usually see it paired with verbs or other nouns, like 苦労の甲斐があった (it was worth the trouble) or 頑張った甲斐があった (trying hard paid off).
You have much <kanji>luck</kanji> in your <kanji>welfare</kanji>, making you have good <vocabulary>welfare</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>well being</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>rice plant</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is a <vocabulary>rice field</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>rice paddy</vocabulary>.
If you <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>rice plant</kanji> then you are doing <vocabulary>rice cultivation</vocabulary>, since you're making it from the seed to the harvest and doing it all!
If you are going to <kanji>defer</kanji> to someone, you are going <vocabulary>to concede</vocabulary> something. I concede / defer this to you.

<kanji>Shift</kanji> something and <kanji>defer</kanji> it somewhere else. This is a <vocabulary>transfer</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assignment</vocabulary>.

This is a formal term used to describe the legal transfer of rights, properties, or liabilities, so it's most commonly seen in official or legal documents.

<kanji>Language</kanji> when you <kanji>defer</kanji> to <kanji>modesty</kanji> is <vocabulary>humble Japanese</vocabulary>. Of course, this doesn't have to refer to Japanese, though it usually does, meaning this could mean <vocabulary>humble language</vocabulary> as well.
The <kanji>modesty</kanji> <kanji>void</kanji> is that big pit you go into when you are showing <vocabulary>modesty</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>humility</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>leap</kanji> so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to leap</vocabulary>. It also means <vocabulary>to jump</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to bounce</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>lively</kanji> <kanji>leap</kanji> is what you do when you have <vocabulary>active participation</vocabulary> in an <vocabulary>activity</vocabulary> and often find <vocabulary>success</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>do great</vocabulary>.

This word is usually used to describe someone's outstanding or remarkable activity in a certain sport, career, or other field or activity. Have a look at the common word combinations for some example usages.
If you <kanji>hop</kanji> and <kanji>leap</kanji> into the air, you probably are doing a <vocabulary>jump</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>leap</vocabulary> into the air.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
A <kanji>gun</kanji> <kanji>kill</kanji> is a <vocabulary>death by shooting</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>gun</kanji>'s <kanji>bullet</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bullet</vocabulary>, though this word can specifically refer to a <vocabulary>rifle bullet</vocabulary> as well (probably because it was mostly rifles that people had way back in the day).
A <kanji>short</kanji> <kanji>gun</kanji> is a <vocabulary>pistol</vocabulary>, because it's not long like a rifle, it's a short gun!
You need to go through a <kanji>paragraph</kanji> in chunks that you can easily see with your <kanji>eye</kanji> so you break it up by <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>.

You know 事 means "occurrence," but it can also mean "matter." So a <kanji>matter</kanji> <kanji>paragraph</kanji> shows the <vocabulary>matter</vocabulary>s, <vocabulary>item</vocabulary>s, or <vocabulary>subject</vocabulary>s that make up a larger issue or discussion at hand.

事項 is a formal word usually seen at the end of another phrase that specifies what matters or items are being referred to, like 注意事項 (matters to be noted) or 協議事項 (items for discussion).
A <kanji>need</kanji>ed <kanji>paragraph</kanji> contains the <vocabulary>important points</vocabulary> of what you want to say.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Steel</kanji> <kanji>material</kanji> is <vocabulary>steel material</vocabulary>. Boom!
If you <kanji>manufacture</kanji> <kanji>steel</kanji> that is <vocabulary>steel manufacture</vocabulary>.
掲載 is <kanji>publication</kanji> so the verb version of that is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>criminal</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> will end up as a <vocabulary>prisoner</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>inmate</vocabulary> if they get caught!

Remember how you learned that 死刑 means "death penalty?" Well a <kanji>criminal</kanji> who has been sentenced to it is a <vocabulary>condemned criminal</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>death row convict</vocabulary>. They're condemned to death.

Something that can <kanji>abstain</kanji> until it's needed makes for good <vocabulary>backup</vocabulary>. Think about it — you don't want backup rushing in too early, right? It should abstain until the backup is actually needed.

Note that 控え isn't used for spares and extras. It's more for necessary backups, like a backup player in sports, a document <vocabulary>copy</vocabulary> for record keeping, or a <vocabulary>receipt stub</vocabulary>.

If you have a <kanji>dependent</kanji> <kanji>nature</kanji>, then even if you go off on your own, you're <vocabulary>still</vocabulary> going to ask for help. Dependent people still need help because that's just how they are.

Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
An <kanji>eyebrow's</kanji> <kanji>hair</kanji> is the individual <vocabulary>eyebrow</vocabulary> hair that makes them up.

The <kanji>address</kanji> <kanji>name</kanji> is the name that's on the address, making it the <vocabulary>addressee</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>name and address</vocabulary>.

This can be used for both physical mail and email.
Someone or something whose 由緒 (lineage) is 正しい (correct) is <vocabulary>of honorable lineage</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>venerable</vocabulary> indeed.

In the <kanji>ume</kanji> season, it <kanji>rain</kanji>s a lot in Japan (and some other East Asian countries). That's why <kanji>ume</kanji> <kanji>rain</kanji> means <vocabulary>rainy season</vocabulary>. It usually happens from the end of May to mid-July, when ume get ready to be harvested. 

Keep in mind this is a seasonal word unique to Japan and East Asia, so you usually don't use it to refer to rainy seasons that happen in other regions of the world.
